bug.description:
/kind bug What steps did you take and what happened: I have MetalLB that is configured to offer external IPs. I have Prometheus running on my cluster and MetalLB is correctly serving IPs for that. Kubeflow deployed correctly and had no errors (other than taking about 15 mins for everything to come ready). The problem is istio-ingress looks like it did not even try for an external IP and defaulted to a NodePort type. <denchmark-code>kubectl get svc -n istio-system NAME TYPE CLUSTER-IP EXTERNAL-IP PORT(S) istio-ingressgateway NodePort 10.233.38.43 <none> 15020:30186/TCP,80:31380/TCP,443:31390/TCP,31400:31400/TCP,15029:30757/TCP,15030:31669/TCP,15031:32675/TCP,15032:31747/TCP,15443:30528/TCP 50m </denchmark-code>
What did you expect to happen: istio-ingress to get an external IP from my MetalLB LoadBalancer Anything else you would like to add: I am doing this using Nvidia's Deepops tools to deploy my k8s cluster. Environment:
Kubeflow version: v0.6.1 kfctl version: kfctl v0.6.1-rc.2-1-g3a37cbc6 Kubernetes platform: k8s Kubernetes version: v1.14.3 OS (e.g. from /etc/os-release): Ubuntu 18.04 server

Currently the implementation for Istio ingress gateway service is set to NodePort by default. If we edit the istio-ingress-gateway service in namespace istio-system to Load Balancer type, you should be able to use MetalLB running with the ingress gateway and get the external IP.
Perfect! Was able to accomplish this with kubectl edit svc istio-ingressgateway -n istio-system and changing the type from NodePort to LoadBalancer.
